channel.title: BBC News - Home

item.title: Afghanistan: Child handed over Kabul airport wall as chaos continues
item.description: Afghans try to scale airport walls and shots are fired as crowds keep trying to flee the Taliban.

item.title: Zaki Anwari: Afghan footballer falls to death from US plane in Kabul
item.description: Zaki Anwari, 19, had played for Afghanistan's national youth team before trying to flee the country.

item.title: Sheffield hotel fall: Boy who died was Afghan refugee
item.description: Five-year-old Mohammed Munib Majeedi and his family arrived in the UK two weeks ago.

item.title: Covid: UK vaccine booster scheme likely to start in September - Sajid Javid
item.description: The proposed rollout of third doses is likely to start in September, the health secretary says.

item.title: Baby bats babble like humans
item.description: Babbling in baby bats bears a striking resemblance to human infants learning to talk, researchers find.

item.title: Morrisons backs US firm's improved takeover offer
item.description: The supermarket has agreed to a bid worth £7bn from a US private equity group, ditching a lower offer from another firm.

item.title: Kabul evacuation: No planes leaving empty says UK defence secretary
item.description: Defence Secretary Ben Wallace says "every hour counts", with up to 10 flights leaving every day.

item.title: OnlyFans to ban sexually explicit content
item.description: The online subscription site will prevent users from posting content showing 'sexually explicit conduct'.

item.title: Nicole Kidman reportedly enters Hong Kong quarantine-free
item.description: Hong Kong media say the Australian star was seen out and about in the city two days after arriving.

item.title: Blue singer Lee Ryan tells court he cannot afford £1,500 fine
item.description: The 38-year-old singer was banned from driving for 12 months and given a fine.

item.title: Stuart Lubbock: Suspect in murder case released without charge
item.description: Stuart Lubbock was found unconscious at Michael Barrymore's house in 2001 and later died.

item.title: Ex-MP Jared O'Mara charged with seven counts of fraud
item.description: Jared O'Mara is charged in relation to alleged fraudulent expenses claims, the CPS say.

item.title: Haiti earthquake: Rescue efforts continue in Les Cayes
item.description: The death toll from the 7.2-magnitude quake is now over 2,000, with many still missing in towns like Les Cayes.

item.title: Wildfires rage across Europe
item.description: A look at some of the fires spreading across Europe - and the rest of the globe.

item.title: Nature: Rattlesnakes' sound 'trick' fools human ears
item.description: Rattlesnakes have evolved a clever method of convincing humans that danger is closer than you think.

item.title: Visa delays hit UK students heading to Spain to study
item.description: Students due to spend a year in Spain as part of their degree are hit with post-Brexit visa delays.

item.title: Can the Paralympics bring lasting change?
item.description: A campaign gets underway to try to improve the lives of the world's 1.2bn disabled people.

item.title: Pride: The fear, regret and elation of coming out
item.description: People explain the anxiety, abuse and absolute joy of the moment they opened up about their sexuality.

item.title: You may go to the ball: Cinderella opens in the West End
item.description: Andrew Lloyd Webber and Emerald Fennel’s reimagining of the classic fairytale debuts in London.

item.title: The White Lotus: HBO comedy-drama attracts rave reviews from critics
item.description: The HBO comedy-drama, which began in the UK on Monday, has received several five-star reviews.

item.title: Hunt for owner of engagement ring found at Tube station
item.description: James Flude, 28, hopes the owner will get in touch after finding the ring at Vauxhall station.

item.title: The Papers: MPs condemn US president, and Johnson 'humiliated'
item.description: Most of Thursday's front pages lead on reaction from UK politicians to the crisis in Afghanistan.

item.title: Afghanistan: Who originally supported Trump's deal with the Taliban?
item.description: UK Defence Secretary Ben Wallace now calls it a "rotten" deal but supported it at the time.

item.title: Afghanistan: Calls to UK veterans mental health helpline double
item.description: Charity Combat Stress says calls to its helpline have doubled since the Taliban took control of Kabul.

item.title: India's living dead: 'They stared at me like I was a ghost'
item.description: If you're dead you can't own land - so if someone obtains your death certificate you could lose everything.

item.title: Haiti earthquake: The forgotten villages cut off from help
item.description: The tremor razed their homes, but these survivors could still die for a lack of basic supplies.

item.title: Changing Rooms: Makeover TV show is back - what did critics think?
item.description: Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen and his leather trousers usher the home makeover show back after 17 years.

item.title: Algeria: The forest fires that led to an artist's lynching
item.description: When Djamel Ben Ismail went to fight forest fires in Algeria, his life was cut short by a raging mob.

item.title: Censor: Video nasty film explores the power of horror
item.description: The film Censor, set during the 80s, delves into impact of the lurid horror movies from that era.

item.title: WeThe15: 'Game-changer' plan for 1.2bn disabled people
item.description: A global campaign is launched to improve the lives of more than 1.2bn disabled people.

item.title: Tigray crisis: Ethiopian teenagers become pawns in propaganda war
item.description: The BBC is told they were forced to fight for Tigray's rebels, but were words put into their mouths?

item.title: MPs vent their fury over Afghanistan - but what impact will it have?
item.description: After a year of flat debates, a full Commons proved harder for the PM to navigate, writes Jessica Parker.

item.title: Brazil hopes the world will get a taste for its favourite spirit
item.description: With domestic sales of cachaça falling last year, Brazilian producers want to export more.

item.title: Afghanistan: The 'pure devastation and guilt' of British-Afghans
item.description: We chat to young people in the UK who have family in Afghanistan, as the Taliban take control.

item.title: How latte art in South Africa led to a job from hell in Oman
item.description: A South African barista was offered a dream opportunity in Oman but unknowingly signed away his freedoms.

item.title: 'Feelgood factor disappeared' - much-changed Tottenham beaten in play-off first leg
item.description: Tottenham boss Nuno Espirito Santo admits their "feelgood factor disappeared" following defeat at Pacos de Ferreira.

item.title: Ten-man Rangers edge out Alashkert to stay on course for Europa League
item.description: Ten-man Rangers avoid a sobering draw at home to Alashkert as Alfredo Morelos' strike keeps them on course for the Europa League group stage.

item.title: Women's Open 2021: Louise Duncan & Georgia Hall impress as Nelly Korda shares lead at Carnoustie
item.description: Scottish amateur Louise Duncan and England's Georgia Hall are one shot off the lead after splendid opening rounds in scoreable conditions at Carnoustie.

item.title: Rafiq accuses Yorkshire of downplaying racism
item.description: Former player Azeem Rafiq accuses Yorkshire of downplaying racism by calling him the victim of "inappropriate behaviour".

item.title: Qarabag 1-0 Aberdeen: Scottish visitors' group hopes still alive despite first-leg defeat in tough conditions
item.description: Aberdeen's Europa Conference League group-stage hopes are still alive despite a first-leg defeat at Qarabag in tough conditions.

item.title: One-Day Cup: Glamorgan beat Durham at Trent Bridge to win first knockout trophy
item.description: Glamorgan beat Durham by 58 runs to win the One-Day Cup at Trent Bridge - their first knockout trophy.

item.title: One-Day Cup: A member of the crowd stumbles over attempting a catch
item.description: A fan attempts to catch a shot hit by Kiran Carlson for six, but fails to do so stumbling over a row of chairs in the process, much to the humour of the Trent Bridge crowd.

item.title: Afghanistan: Danger lies on Kabul's airport road to freedom
item.description: As thousands try to flee Afghanistan, the main route to the capital's airport has become treacherous.

item.title: Afghanistan: A woman's story of life under the Taliban in 1999
item.description: Taliban rule in 1999 - an Afghan woman recalls the day her father disappeared.

item.title: UK woman tells of airport dash to flee Kabul
item.description: A councillor who was visiting family in the country she had left aged three tells of her evacuation.

item.title: Biden on Afghanistan fact-checked
item.description: How consistent is President Biden in his comments on Afghanistan?

item.title: Afghanistan: Protesters wave national flag at Independence Day protests
item.description: Afghan protesters mark Independence Day with the national flag, days after the Taliban takeover.

item.title: 'All your sacrifices have just been in vain, sweetheart'
item.description: Families affected by the Afghan war reveal their sadness and anger at the Taliban's swift resurgence.

item.title: Afghanistan crisis: 'Many here will be deeply fearful for their future'
item.description: The BBC's Secunder Kermani reports from the heart of Kabul during the unfolding crisis in Afghanistan.

item.title: Afghan interpreter who worked for UK begs PM for help
item.description: Ahmed, who fears Taliban reprisals, is desperate for him and his family to be evacuated from Kabul.

item.title: What is Sharia law? What does it mean for women in Afghanistan?
item.description: The Taliban say they will govern Afghanistan according to Sharia, or Islamic law

item.title: Afghanistan: How many asylum seekers has the UK taken in?
item.description: The UK government says it will resettle up to 20,000 Afghan refugees, but warns it will "take time".

item.title: Afghanistan: 'I feel lucky to leave but we must not forget those left behind'
item.description: The UK government says 306 UK nationals and 2,052 Afghans have been flown out of the country so far.

item.title: Afghanistan: Joe Biden said chaos was 'inevitable'
item.description: In an interview with ABC, Joe Biden said nobody could have anticipated the speed of the Taliban takeover.

item.title: What are the travel rules for Spain, Portugal, Malta and other holiday hotspots?
item.description: What you need to know about going to Portugal, Spain, Greece, France, Malta, Italy and Turkey.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The progress made in vaccinating the country's adult population, as more than 47 million people have received at least one dose.

item.title: Covid rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: Do I have to self-isolate if I'm fully vaccinated?
item.description: Self-isolation rules have now been relaxed across the UK.

item.title: 'How I found out my dad was a best-selling sex writer'
item.description: Sara Faith Alterman was always close to her father. Then she learned he was concealing a secret.

item.title: Plymouth shooting: Inside the dark world of 'incels'
item.description: Who are the angry young men who describe themselves as "involuntarily celibate"?

item.title: Wildfires: How Portuguese club Tondela drove through the flames
item.description: In Tondela, the bond between club and fans was at its strongest during the night in October 2017 when nobody slept.

item.title: Malta: The teenagers pulled from the sea and accused of terrorism
item.description: How three teenagers rescued from the Mediterranean Sea ended up in Malta accused of terrorism.
